Ah yeah! I‚Äôve been working on that as well. I just bought some new things (second hand) and the sizes varied widely. I‚Äôve been cutting tags out of my clothes for that reason; it doesn‚Äôt matter what the size is, as long as it fits and I feel good in it :)
Incredible! Congrats to you for self-advocating and prioritizing your health ü•≥

Thank you for sharing this! I got rid of my scale a few months ago, and the change has been really surprising. I struggled with the idea of not knowing my weight, because ‚Äúhow would I know what to feel about myself??‚Äù, (haha).  There were so many days when I felt great, weighed myself, and then my day was ruined because of the number I saw. But now, not knowing is so liberating. My doctor and care team know, and I don‚Äôt need to know the number. The number is irrelevant to me and my life, and my worth is not connected to how much I weigh.
You look hella incredible!
Your smile is gorgeous!
Amazing, I love it!
Congratulations! You look great too :)

Also! Him ‚Äúgiving up‚Äù on you doesn‚Äôt have anything to do with you as a person or who you are; you‚Äôre just as valuable as ever, even if he didn‚Äôt see it. Just wanted to say that, because I always felt like the way people treated me meant something about who I was, or what I deserved. It has nothing to do with us, and everything to do with them and who they are.

You‚Äôre welcome!! 

Ahhh lol, I‚Äôve been there!!! That obsessive feeling is so awful, like ‚Äúcome on, just do the thing I want and everything will be perfect, why are you doing this to me??‚Äù My therapist once told me that feeling so intensely towards people (like that instant intense connection) signifies how desperately we want to connect with others, and so we can kind of jump the gun. Whenever I feel things intensely, I try to validate how I feel, like ‚Äúit‚Äôs understandable that I‚Äôm excited about this person because I thought we had a great time, it‚Äôs understandable that I feel upset and obsessive now because I don‚Äôt know what happened and I feel like I don‚Äôt have control‚Äù and then yeah, recognizing that dwelling on it is only going to cause you more discomfort and pain (even tho for me it always feels like that‚Äôs the solution). It sucks to shake your self loose, but letting go is so freeing. In situations like this, I avoid checking Instagram, or read old messages  etc, because it‚Äôs only going to give the obsession more fuel. Get it out of sight, and then cram your brain full of other pleasant stimuli. Eventually, he‚Äôll fade away. 

Also, try to learn from this experience :) I have a bad habit of doing the same thing...I‚Äôd get excited about someone and start planning our whole lives together and how great it would be; and then if things don‚Äôt work, it would be even more devastating. Now, when I catch myself having thoughts like that, I validate the urge, like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm exited and it‚Äôs understandable that I am because I like this person for these reasons‚Äù and then I  don‚Äôt let myself go there. It‚Äôs been challenging, but the more I do it, the easier it‚Äôs getting. The obsession etc doesn‚Äôt happen as much when there isn‚Äôt that source material for it.

This is my instinct too. As for staying rational: try to remember that sometimes people‚Äôs choices have nothing to do with you, and try to focus on letting go of control over a situation you can‚Äôt control; you can‚Äôt control his actions, but you can control your own :) focus on doing good things for yourself; when I‚Äôm feeling unhinged or obsessive over other people, I try to circle back and do something to ‚Äústrengthen‚Äù myself; putting the energy I‚Äôm wasting (on other people) back into myself by doing chores, hobbies, whatever that will make my life a better place. Even if it doesn‚Äôt feel ‚Äúgood‚Äù in the moment, in the long term it‚Äôs investing in your own well being. 

Also, good for you for saying you weren‚Äôt comfortable yet with kissing! Boundaries ftw!
Congrats and best of luck with school!
Happy birthday!!! Hope it‚Äôs a great one ü•≥

I like eating yogurt when I don‚Äôt have an appetite, especially Icelandic yogurt because it‚Äôs pretty high in protein. Juice and smoothies too.

Thanks so much for sharing this! It didn‚Äôt occur to me that DBT courses could be available online, and this is really cool. DBT has personally been a game changer; I have real hope for the first time in a long time, and I‚Äôm only half way through a 16 week course. I hope you find it as helpful for yourself!

Unfortunately I can only tell you what happened/worked for me, I don‚Äôt know your full situation or what things are like where you live. Where I am, you can at least see a general practitioner and it‚Äôs covered by health care. I‚Äôd been working with my gp for years re: feelings of depression anxiety etc, and so I had a paper trail showing how long it had been going on for and what I was trying to do to get better.  If you don‚Äôt even have access to that though...I‚Äôm so sorry. 

Believe me, I feel your frustration and I wish I could give you a simple answer. It‚Äôs unfair and f*ed up that society doesn‚Äôt value healthcare and especially mental health care the way that it should; that care is kept behind extremely high pay walls and isn‚Äôt accessible to everyone as easily as it should be. It‚Äôs not okay, and it‚Äôs not okay that you‚Äôre in a position where you feel like you have no options. Like I said, I used to fantasize about getting into accidents and hospitalized, because I felt like there truly weren‚Äôt any other options to escape how miserable I was. 

In the past I‚Äôve been able to find counselling services that were paid on a sliding scale (ended up being free for me because of how low income I was), and have also been able to find reduced cost counselling by seeing student therapists (still completing training). I‚Äôve also recently discovered free resources locally, including the DBT course I‚Äôm taking now at a local hospital. Maybe you can find something similar in your area, maybe you can‚Äôt...but I hope there could be something available near you.

Hey! You‚Äôre definitely not alone, and my heart goes out to you.

I was in the same situation...my entire adult life (basically the last decade), work has caused me extreme stress, daily panic attacks, dread, etc. I used to cry at my desk or in the bathroom, every day. I used to fantasize about getting into accidents or getting sick and hospitalized, just so I could have a valid excuse not to have to go to work. I wanted to work though, to be independent and stable and capable, to have money and live the life that I wanted to. 

I‚Äôm 30 now and have no ‚Äúcareer‚Äù to speak of, just a string of meaningless jobs that made me miserable; I was lucky to be able to receive money from EI (employment insurance) for about a year) and spent that time devoted to working on my health. When my EI ran out and I was forced to go back to work, all the negative symptoms above came right back. I tried to go back to school, to learn skills for a job I thought might make me happier...but it lead to a major breakdown instead. 

I‚Äôm now on disability and working full time on recovery. I used to also fantasize about this...but never thought I was ‚Äúsick‚Äù enough to qualify. Now that I‚Äôve been approved for it, I feel like a huge weight has been lifted from me, and I actually have the mental space to focus on getting better. I know it‚Äôs not for everyone and definitely not an easy process, but if you‚Äôve been working with a dr/team and have adequate supporting documents, it‚Äôs worth looking into. 

Sending you lots of good vibes ‚ú®‚ú®‚ú®

I‚Äôve also wondered about this for myself; I remember being pretty young, watching porn and fantasizing about being old enough to have all the sex I wanted. I think it has something to do with wanting to be wanted.
Yeah that‚Äôs a good thing for me to focus on. I tend to let everyone in, because I don‚Äôt want to upset anyone ‚Äî which leads a lot to me being upset haha.

Hey! You‚Äôre definitely not a monster, you‚Äôre a person struggling to cope the best they can while working with a very challenging disorder. BPD makes things confusing and complex, and it sounds like you‚Äôre working on getting better. Please try to take a moment to have some compassion for yourself, because being judgemental and angry at yourself will only make things worse. 

Facing your fears is hard, but it‚Äôs doable. You are more powerful than you give yourself credit for; I think we all are. It sounds like you‚Äôve identified some things that are causing you pain, which is a good first step! I don‚Äôt want to give u too much advice because tbh I don‚Äôt always know what I‚Äôm doing either lol, but you‚Äôre not alone üíñ

My heart goes out to you, I relate to this so much and have been having the same realizations over the past few months...that behaviours that feel right to me are, in fact, unhealthy. I recognize that this is the reality, but it‚Äôs still so hard to not get the things I want/desperately crave. It‚Äôs frustrating to know the solution isn‚Äôt getting what I want, but changing what I  want into something reasonable and healthy, and then working to get it. I just want to be smothered with love and have an obsessively close relationship, ugh lol.

I do this too! I‚Äôm trying to get better at recognizing what I‚Äôm starting to do it, and call myself out with ‚Äúnope, I‚Äôm not going to play this game‚Äù. Haha. Sometimes it works, sometimes not so much.

Recognizing the connection between drinking and depression is what finally got me to stop drinking. I spent a lot of time convincing myself that ‚Äúmaybe this time it‚Äôll be different‚Äù or that ‚Äújust a few‚Äù wouldn‚Äôt hurt me, and then wake up the next day with an emotional hangover that would land me in a severe depression for several day‚Äôs after. Thank you for sharing this, and congrats on your progress!

That‚Äôs amazing news and super encouraging! I‚Äôm proud of you, and feel reassurance about the value of choosing to commit to slow change.

My heart goes out to you having to deal with what sounds like an unsupportive and frustrating relationship. Your post was beautifully worded though and reading it helped me feel a bit more stable this morning, and I‚Äôm really needing it. Thanks friend.

Honestly, I‚Äôve personally found that DBT has been giving me a lot of the skills that you just described. I hated CBT and found it not very helpful for the reasons why you just stated: CBT skills ‚Äúhelped‚Äù me, but didn‚Äôt address the underlying issues. I was very skeptical of DBT after not finding much success with CBT, but it‚Äôs been a total game changer for me.

I was diagnosed by a psychologist who did a formal psychological assessment on me (which cost A LOT, and thankfully my ex‚Äôs insurance covered). She interviewed me for a few hours and I laid it alllll out, held nothing back. I‚Äôd also been ‚Äúdiagnosed‚Äù as having depression/anxiety by my family dr/gp and had worked with her on that for almost a decade with little to no success. I had also been told by other therapists that I couldn‚Äôt possibly have BPD, but I got the diagnosis once I was completely honest about everything that had been going on with me.

Hey there! I‚Äôm so sorry you‚Äôre struggling rn and feeling down; I know how hard that is, and am sending you lots of love! 

In one of my groups, we recently discussed how holding on to some old/unhealthy behaviours can actually help us to learn new/healthier behaviours, because it helps to give you some comfort and security while trying new things. 

That being said, if looking forward to a nice breakfast brings you joy and helps you get out of bed in the morning, I say go for it! You might want to cut down on fast food/junk in general, but giving yourself permission to enjoy a coffee and bagel on morning that you could use the pick me up is most likely going to give you the comfort and mental energy you need to then make healthier choices in the rest of your day :) and when you do give yourself that permission, try to really, fully enjoy that food without any guilt or shame. Remind yourself that you deserve to be happy, and you deserve to enjoy food. Try eating slowly and mindfully and really pay attention to sensations while eating so you can work on actually enjoying the thing :) That‚Äôs helped me a lot.
That‚Äôs very true! Thanks for sharing your perspective :)
Hey there! I‚Äôm dying to know what the rest of your shirt says.

Oh absolutely, and I don‚Äôt advocate leaving in the middle of a date without saying something. I‚Äôve never bailed on a date in progress, but have gone on dates with people who were boring, had bad hygiene etc, and I feel like in that situation, it‚Äôs kind of cruel to tell them exactly why you don‚Äôt want another date. I don‚Äôt want to hurt people‚Äôs feelings, and so I‚Äôm not going to say something like ‚Äúsorry, I don‚Äôt want to ever see you again because you‚Äôre boring‚Äù
You look gorgeous! And good for you for using such a great coping skill.

Thank you so much for sharing this! I was just diagnosed with BPD in 2019, at age 30, and was so angry and hopeless at first. I was the biggest skeptic re: DBT etc, but after even just a few weeks I‚Äôm seeing improvements in myself. I love hearing from others who are further in their recovery than I am; it gives me so much hope to know that this stuff can actually make a difference and that a better life is possible.

Totally! I love radical acceptance for this reason, and being able to better differentiate between what I can control and what I can‚Äôt. I‚Äôm feeling less upset in general because I‚Äôm not wasting energy on things that I can‚Äôt change, and directing it into places that I can.

Thanks so much for sharing this! I‚Äôve been slowly figuring this out over the past few months, and it‚Äôs amazing to see the changes in myself now that I‚Äôm challenging myself to shift my thinking. The problems aren‚Äôt out there, they‚Äôre in here, and only I can truly solve them.
Congratulations, that‚Äôs so fantastic!!
Because it‚Äôs still awkward/hard to explicitly reject someone and state specifically why, and I don‚Äôt want to hurt feelings.

Hey, you‚Äôre not alone in this! The same thing happens to me: I have supportive friends and family, and I start to get sad around the time that parties or hangouts wind down. I also feel panicky when I don‚Äôt have social plans for a few days in a row, even though I know that I have tons of people in my life that care about me. Sometimes I feel like I‚Äôm not even real when other people aren‚Äôt around; like the old ‚Äúif a tree falls in the forest and no one is there to hear, does it make a sound?‚Äù But ‚Äúif no one is around to observe me, do I even exist?‚Äù

My instincts tell me that the solution is to work harder at making people like me/want me, so that they won‚Äôt leave, and if they do leave it means that I failed somehow....but that‚Äôs unrealistic and the reality is that sometimes we all have to be alone by ourselves. I can‚Äôt change reality be denying it, so I realize that what I really need to work on is liking myself and being comfortable by myself/with only my own company. 

I‚Äôm really working at making time alone something to enjoy and not something to dread, mostly by trying to focus on things that I can do alone that I love that I can‚Äôt necessarily do when other people are around: like submersing myself in art/hobbies, singing out loud to music I like, taking a bath and painting my nails etc. Im going to have to spend time alone, I might as well learn how to enjoy it and make it pleasurable for myself (although LOL I wish it was as easy at that sounds).

I feel like religion anxiety (among a lot of other things) contributed to my BPD too; something I didn‚Äôt realize until I was older, and had overcome it. Being taught as a child that I was always be watched, and judged by God was awful. I was raised catholic, and went to catholic school, so I got all of the info, but because of my (single) mum‚Äôs work schedule we never went to Church. I was convinced that no matter how ‚Äúgood‚Äù of a person I was, because I didn‚Äôt go to Church, I was going to hell. It got to the point where I considered going to Church by myself in university, not because I believed, but ‚Äújust in case‚Äù.

Sending you and your family so much love right now. I‚Äôve been where you are; the pain is so real, the fear and uncertainty; but you were there, and you did everything you could to help the person you love.  I‚Äôll be keeping you and your brother in my thoughts üíñ
You‚Äôre so welcome üíñ

Pregnancy, relationships and mental health are all challenging in their own right, so I can appreciate how awful and heartbreaking this must have been. I hope you‚Äôre able to do something nice for yourself, like take a bath or have a treat, and know that even tho the pain feels endless, it won‚Äôt last forever üíñ

I feel this really hard üíñ

I‚Äôve recently been stuck on feeling like I‚Äôll never be loved as much as I want/paid enough attention to/cherished enough etc. Two things I‚Äôve been doing: researching healthy attachment/relationships so that I more readily recognize behaviour that ‚Äúfeels right‚Äù to me but is actually a sign of an unhealthy relationship; and redirecting excess loving energy inward.

I have a lot of love to give, and coincidentally (lol) happen to crave a lot love. Learning how to do that is really hard, but so far working on it has been beneficial to me.

Hey! I‚Äôve struggled with my weight all my life, and have only just now recognized the connection between my disordered eating and my BPD (was diagnosed with both an eating disorder and BPD summer 2019). 

It sounds like you‚Äôre putting an awful lot of pressure on yourself, which in my experience is never helpful. Going on ‚Äúdiets‚Äù, even if it was just wanting to ‚Äúbe healthier and eat better‚Äù was always a huge trigger for me because it felt like so much judgement and pressure; I would always try to do too much, would burn out, and then judge and hate myself for it. 

My advice to you is to focus on adding small changes to your existing routines, and not to stress too much about not doing ‚Äúunhealthy things‚Äù.  Add a walk on days you feel up to it; eat whole/nutritious foods when you can. Holding on to some old, unhealthy patterns of behaviour (like say, eating chips) can help you feel safe/comforted enough to feel up to the challenge of trying something new (like adding a walk to your routine). 

Also, try to focus more on your personal relationship with food and how it makes you feel, as well as the relationship between how you‚Äôre feeling and what you‚Äôre eating.  Try to eat mindfully and enjoy things. If I want a treat, or some comfort food, I have it and I pay attention to it while I eat so that my brain actually processes that enjoyment and it registers. I‚Äôve been finding this really helpful! 

Sleep too is huge; I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs one of the first things to try and improve, because not being well rested will make everything so much more challenging. 

Hope some of this was helpful!
Absolutely yes...food, clothes, $50 at the drugstore on nothing; buying things because I think it‚Äôll make me happy, but it never really does.

I‚Äôve been going through something similar lately...I‚Äôve been feeling so alone that spending a night by myself makes me feel panicky. I have an amazing partner and friends, but can‚Äôt get (and shouldn‚Äôt reasonably expect) the level of attention that my BPD wants. I understand that people have their own lives, but it doesn‚Äôt make me feel less alone.
I feel this üíñ

I have BPD and have (unfortunately) been in your boyfriend‚Äôs position. It sounds to me like maybe he‚Äôs having times when he‚Äôs feeling insecure about the relationship and wants reassurance...but it going about it in the wrong way. (I‚Äôve done this A LOT). 

If you haven‚Äôt already, I would recommend talking about things at an neutral time when you‚Äôre both in a clear/calm state of mind. Reasoning and rationality are usually out the window during a meltdown (for me at least). Be honest about your feelings, and give him space to reply, and make it about supporting each other and moving forward. It‚Äôll hopefully help with understanding what/how he‚Äôs feeling, and he can think about why he has those feelings, and see if there‚Äôs anything he/you can do to meet those needs. Making  a plan together that y‚Äôall can follow when things get escalated might also be a good idea (like, when I feel overwhelmed or explosive, I need time to myself, listen to music, go for a walk etc etc). In moments of crisis, you can refer to the plan together and it‚Äôll hopefully help things play out more smoothly. 

That being said...if it does feel like abuse to you, I think it‚Äôs important to do what‚Äôs best for you and your wellbeing.  

Feel free to DM me if you like.

I‚Äôm sorry. I also isolate myself when I‚Äôm at my lowest. 

Maybe try to look at this as an opportunity to take a break from what you were doing (going out, downtown etc) and find some new places/ways to have fun, make yourself feel good and have some space from the place that makes you uncomfortable. 

And most importantly, remember that nothing lasts forever, even when it feels like it will üíñ

I‚Äôm so sorry that you had such a terrible experience. 

Please try to remember that 1) you told him not to touch you, multiple times and that 2) just because you weren‚Äôt being raped, doesn‚Äôt mean you deserved to be touched against your will! 

You reacted in a difficult situation and didn‚Äôt ask for him to be beaten up by a group of other people. You can‚Äôt control what other people do.
